title: Cultural Movements That Imagined the Future
description: How Cyberpunk, Rave, and Burning Man prepared the cultural soil for cyberdelics.

sections.title: Cyberpunk—The Fictional Blueprint

media.alt: Cyberpunk book covers and neon cityscape

sections.content: In the 1980s, writers like William Gibson (Neuromancer) and Neal Stephenson (Snow Crash) imagined worlds where technology and consciousness directly interfaced. These novels established cultural templates: neural interfaces, virtual reality, and hackable identities. They made the future feel inevitable.

sections.title: Rave Culture—Electronic Transcendence
sections.content: Rave culture showed that technology (lights, electronic music) could facilitate collective transcendence. Ravers discovered that technology could create shared altered states—the same principle cyberdelics would later use, just through different media.

sections.title: Burning Man—Art Meets Technology
sections.content: Burning Man became a testing ground for blending technology with radical self-expression. It demonstrated that tech-enhanced experiences could create awe, foster community, and integrate with spirituality rather than oppose it.

sections.title: Digital Art and Fractal Culture
sections.content: Artists discovered that algorithms could produce images comparable to mystical visions (fractals). Works like Char Davies' Osmose created contemplative virtual spaces, proving technology could serve spiritual expression.

sections.title: Cultural Preparation Complete
sections.content: These movements prepared the cultural soil. They created communities, language, and demand for tech-consciousness fusion. When VR returned in the 2010s, the culture was ready.
